conversation.content: [surprised] Oh, I didn't... I didn't expect to see anyone else here today, especially not, um, well, especially not you, Sarah. [quietly] I can come back later if you need some time alone with her.
[hesitantly] No, it's... it's okay, really. [pause] I guess we both remembered what today was, huh? Three years and somehow it still feels like yesterday and a lifetime ago all at once.

[warmly] Your mother used to say that grief was like, uh, like waves, you know? [softly] Sometimes they knock you down, sometimes they're just gentle reminders, but they never really stop coming entirely.
[bitter] Yeah well, she said a lot of things. [sighs] Like how you two were going to grow old together, how you'd always be there, but here we are and it's just... it's just us now, isn't it?

[regretful] I know I haven't been, um, I mean, after the funeral I kind of disappeared and that wasn't fair to you. [clearing throat] You lost your mother and then essentially lost me too, and I'm sorry for that.
Honestly, I didn't know if you'd want me around anymore, like, without Mom being the connection between us, what were we supposed to be to each other, you know?
[firmly] You're still my daughter, Sarah. [voice breaking] Maybe not by blood, but I raised you from the time you were eight years old, taught you to drive, walked you down the aisle at your wedding.
But you never adopted me, never made it official, and I always wondered if that meant something, like maybe you were keeping one foot out the door just in case.

[frustrated] That's not... God, that's not what it was about at all. [exhales] Your biological father was still alive then, and your mother thought, well, she thought it might complicate things legally.
[shaky voice] You know what the hardest part is? [pause] I still want to call you when something good happens, or when I need advice, but I don't know if I have that right anymore.

[empathetically] You have every right, sweetheart, every single right in the world. [sighs] I've been staring at my phone for months wanting to call you but not knowing if you'd even want to hear from me.
Mom would be so angry at us right now, wouldn't she? Standing here at her grave, basically strangers, when she spent fifteen years making us a family.
[chuckling] She'd probably give us that look, you know the one, where she'd tilt her head and purse her lips like we were being the most ridiculous people on the planet.
[warmly] And then she'd make us sit down at the kitchen table and talk it out over coffee and those terrible store-bought cookies she always insisted were just as good as homemade. [laughs softly]
[gently] I still have a box of them in my pantry, can't bring myself to throw them out or eat them. [pause] It's like if I keep them there, maybe she'll walk through the door and open them herself.
[crying while speaking] I do the same thing with her voicemails, just... just listening to her say 'Hi honey, it's Mom' over and over because I'm terrified I'll forget what her voice sounded like.
[softly] Would you maybe want to, I don't know, grab coffee after this? [hesitantly] We could go to that place she liked, the one with the mismatched chairs and the really strong espresso?
[relieved] Yeah, I'd... I'd really like that actually. [sniffling] Maybe we can figure out how to be a family again, even if it's just the two of us now trying to honor what she built.
[quietly] Just the two of us.

[warmly] That's enough though, isn't it? [pause] I mean, Mom always said family wasn't about blood, it was about showing up, and, well, here we both are, showing up for her and maybe... maybe for each other too.

scenario: A stepfather unexpectedly encounters his adult stepdaughter at her mother's grave on the third anniversary of her death, forcing them to confront their estranged relationship.
